Lily Ross Taylor
There is one apparent difficulty in this dating.  Letter 23 was taken to Atticus by Numerius Numestius whom Atticus had commended to Cicero.  In 20,  1 and 22,  7 ( two letters which I date after 23 and 24 ) Cicero answers Atticus' inquiries about Numestius.  But it is noteworthy that,  in describing his friendly treatment of Numestius ( in amicitiam recepiy accepi in amicitiam ) ^ Cicero uses the perfect tense.  There is nothing to prove that Numestius is still with Cicero. 
There is an additional letter whidi needs to be considered,  II 25.  It was written after Cicero received an answer to II 20,  and perhaps also to 21 and 22,  in which he had reported on Varro's attitude.  If one allows a month for the reply to reach Rome ( the minimum time would have been perhaps twenty days ),  it should be dated about August 20 to 28.  The date of the letter is of interest because it seems to fix the time of the pro Flacco in August.  It is significant that in that oration Cicero refers to his own vague involvement in the charges of Vettius ( 96 ) ; nos iam ah indicibus nominamur,  in nos crimina finguntur,  nobis pericula com - parantur
Now that I have dated the Vettius affair in mid - July before Bibulus' postponement of the comitia,  I venture to try,  on the basis of the date,  to find some explanation of the confusing incident.  It happened,  according to my dating,  in the middle of the campaign for all the offices,  which normally occupied the month of July.  Since Vettius in his charges in the senate involved a consular candidate,  and since in the public meeting the next day he mentioned a candidate for the praetorship,  some connection of the incident with the elections seems clear.  Caesar had been showing deep concern for the election of magistrates on whom he could depend.  Under the lex Сатрапа ( ad Att.  II 18,  2 ) he had required all candidates to take oath in a public meeting that they would not impugn the land grants under the Julian laws,  and thereby he had eliminated one candidate for the tribunate,  an upright man who would not take the oath.  But men whom Caesar did not wish to see in office had,  presumably after taking the oath,  remained in the contest. 
The fact is that Caesar,  in spite of his power over the urban mob which voted on his laws,  did not have adequate strength in the elective assemblies,  particularly in the centuriate assembly whidi chose consuls
10.  In making the following tentative list of dates for the eight letters,  I have assumed that messenger service to Epirus would not have been available every day,  and have therefore allowed several days between letters : i8,  about July 2—6,  the time of the gladiatorial show and of the professto for tribunitial candidates,  twenty - four days before the comitia ; 19,  about July 8 ; 23,  about July 13 ; 24,  about July 17,  suming that the senatorial meeting occurred on the 15 th or i6th ; 20,  about July 21 ; 21,  July 25 or shortly afterwards ; 22,  July 26—31,  probably after the 28th ; 25,  about August 20 to 28.
